text: 19 While Admiral Croft was taking this walk with Anne , and expressing his wish of getting Captain Wentworth to Bath , Captain Wentworth was already on his way thither .

text: Before Mrs Croft had written , he was arrived , and the very next time Anne walked out , she saw him .
text_tokenized: Before Mrs Croft had written , he was arrived , and the very next time Anne walked out , she saw him .

text: Mr Elliot was attending his two cousins and Mrs Clay .
text_tokenized: Mr Elliot was attending his two cousins and Mrs Clay .

text: They were in Milsom Street .
text_tokenized: They were in Milsom Street .

text: It began to rain , not much , but enough to make shelter desirable for women , and quite enough to make it very desirable for Miss Elliot to have the advantage of being conveyed home in Lady Dalrymple 's carriage , which was seen waiting at a little distance ; she , Anne , and Mrs Clay , therefore , turned into Molland 's , while Mr Elliot stepped to Lady Dalrymple , to request her assistance .
text_tokenized: It began to rain , not much , but enough to make shelter desirable for women , and quite enough to make it very desirable for Miss Elliot to have the advantage of being conveyed home in Lady Dalrymple 's carriage , which was seen waiting at a little distance ; she , Anne , and Mrs Clay , therefore , turned into Molland 's , while Mr Elliot stepped to Lady Dalrymple , to request her assistance .

text: He soon joined them again , successful , of course ; Lady Dalrymple would be most happy to take them home , and would call for them in a few minutes . Her ladyship 's carriage was a barouche , and did not hold more than four with any comfort . Miss Carteret was with her mother ; consequently it was not reasonable to expect accommodation for all the three Camden Place ladies . There could be no doubt as to Miss Elliot . Whoever suffered inconvenience , she must suffer none , but it occupied a little time to settle the point of civility between the other two .

text: The rain was a mere trifle , and Anne was most sincere in preferring a walk with Mr Elliot .

text: But the rain was also a mere trifle to Mrs Clay ; she would hardly allow it even to drop at all , and her boots were so thick !

text: It was fixed accordingly , that Mrs Clay should be of the party in the carriage ; and they had just reached this point , when Anne , as she sat near the window , descried , most decidedly and distinctly , Captain Wentworth walking down the street .

text: Her start was perceptible only to herself ; but she instantly felt that she was the greatest simpleton in the world , the most unaccountable and absurd !
text_tokenized: Her start was perceptible only to herself ; but she instantly felt that she was the greatest simpleton in the world , the most unaccountable and absurd !

text: For a few minutes she saw nothing before her ; it was all confusion . She was lost , and when she had scolded back her senses , she found the others still waiting for the carriage , and Mr Elliot ( always obliging ) just setting off for Union Street on a commission of Mrs Clay 's . She now felt a great inclination to go to the outer door ; she wanted to see if it rained .

text: She was sent back , however , in a moment by the entrance of Captain Wentworth himself , among a party of gentlemen and ladies , evidently his acquaintance , and whom he must have joined a little below Milsom Street .

text: He was more obviously struck and confused by the sight of her than she had ever observed before ; he looked quite red .

text: For the first time , since their renewed acquaintance , she felt that she was betraying the least sensibility of the two .

text: She had the advantage of him in the preparation of the last few moments .

text: All the overpowering , blinding , bewildering , first effects of strong surprise were over with her .

text: Still , however , she had enough to feel !
text_tokenized: Still , however , she had enough to feel !

text: It was agitation , pain , pleasure , a something between delight and misery .
text_tokenized: It was agitation , pain , pleasure , a something between delight and misery .

text: He spoke to her , and then turned away .
text_tokenized: He spoke to her , and then turned away .

text: The character of his manner was embarrassment .
text_tokenized: The character of his manner was embarrassment .

text: She could not have called it either cold or friendly , or anything so certainly as embarrassed . After a short interval , however , he came towards her , and spoke again .
text_tokenized: She could not have called it either cold or friendly , or anything so certainly as embarrassed . After a short interval , however , he came towards her , and spoke again .

text: Mutual enquiries on common subjects passed : neither of them , probably , much the wiser for what they heard , and Anne continuing fully sensible of his being less at ease than formerly .
text_tokenized: Mutual enquiries on common subjects passed : neither of them , probably , much the wiser for what they heard , and Anne continuing fully sensible of his being less at ease than formerly .

text: They had by dint of being so very much together , got to speak to each other with a considerable portion of apparent indifference and calmness ; but he could not do it now .

text: Time had changed him , or Louisa had changed him .

text: He looked very well , not as if he had been suffering in health or spirits , and he talked of Uppercross , of the Musgroves , nay , even of Louisa , and had even a momentary look of his own arch significance as he named her ; but yet it was Captain Wentworth not comfortable , not easy , not able to feign that he was . It did not surprise , but it grieved Anne to observe that Elizabeth would not know him .

text: She saw that he saw Elizabeth , that Elizabeth saw him , that there was complete internal recognition on each side ; she was convinced that he was ready to be acknowledged as an acquaintance , expecting it , and she had the pain of seeing her sister turn away with unalterable coldness .

text: Lady Dalrymple 's carriage , for which Miss Elliot was growing very impatient , now drew up ; the servant came in to announce it . It was beginning to rain again , and altogether there was a delay , and a bustle , and a talking , which must make all the little crowd in the shop understand that Lady Dalrymple was calling to convey Miss Elliot .

text: At last Miss Elliot and her friend , unattended but by the servant , ( for there was no cousin returned ) , were walking off ; and Captain Wentworth , watching them , turned again to Anne , and by manner , rather than words , was offering his services to her .

text: " I am much obliged to you , " was her answer , " but I am not going with them . The carriage would not accommodate so many .

text: After a moment 's pause he said : " Though I came only yesterday , I have equipped myself properly for Bath already , you see , " ( pointing to a new umbrella ) ; " I wish you would make use of it , if you are determined to walk ; though I think it would be more prudent to let me get you a chair . " She was very much obliged to him , but declined it all , repeating her conviction , that the rain would come to nothing at present , and adding , " I am only waiting for Mr Elliot .

text: There was no difference between him and the man who had stood on the steps at Lyme , admiring Anne as she passed , except in the air and look and manner of the privileged relation and friend . He came in with eagerness , appeared to see and think only of her , apologised for his stay , was grieved to have kept her waiting , and anxious to get her away without further loss of time and before the rain increased ; and in another moment they walked off together , her arm under his , a gentle and embarrassed glance , and a " Good morning to you ! " being all that she had time for , as she passed away .

But it was more probable that he should be come to stay .

text: It had cost her something to encounter Lady Russell 's surprise ; and now , if she were by any chance to be thrown into company with Captain Wentworth , her imperfect knowledge of the matter might add another shade of prejudice against him .

text: The following morning Anne was out with her friend , and for the first hour , in an incessant and fearful sort of watch for him in vain ; but at last , in returning down Pulteney Street , she distinguished him on the right hand pavement at such a distance as to have him in view the greater part of the street .

text: There were many other men about him , many groups walking the same way , but there was no mistaking him .

text: She looked instinctively at Lady Russell ; but not from any mad idea of her recognising him so soon as she did herself .

text: No , it was not to be supposed that Lady Russell would perceive him till they were nearly opposite . She looked at her however , from time to time , anxiously ; and when the moment approached which must point him out , though not daring to look again ( for her own countenance she knew was unfit to be seen ) , she was yet perfectly conscious of Lady Russell 's eyes being turned exactly in the direction for him-- of her being , in short , intently observing him .
text_tokenized: No , it was not to be supposed that Lady Russell would perceive him till they were nearly opposite . text: She could thoroughly comprehend the sort of fascination he must possess over Lady Russell 's mind , the difficulty it must be for her to withdraw her eyes , the astonishment she must be feeling that eight or nine years should have passed over him , and in foreign climes and in active service too , without robbing him of one personal grace ! At last , Lady Russell drew back her head .

text: " You will wonder , " said she , " what has been fixing my eye so long ; but I was looking after some window - curtains , which Lady Alicia and Mrs Frankland were telling me of last night .

text: They described the drawing - room window - curtains of one of the houses on this side of the way , and this part of the street , as being the handsomest and best hung of any in Bath , but could not recollect the exact number , and I have been trying to find out which it could be ; but I confess I can see no curtains hereabouts that answer their description . "

text: Anne sighed and blushed and smiled , in pity and disdain , either at her friend or herself . The part which provoked her most , was that in all this waste of foresight and caution , she should have lost the right moment for seeing whether he saw them .

text: A day or two passed without producing anything .

text: The theatre or the rooms , where he was most likely to be , were not fashionable enough for the Elliots , whose evening amusements were solely in the elegant stupidity of private parties , in which they were getting more and more engaged ; and Anne , wearied of such a state of stagnation , sick of knowing nothing , and fancying herself stronger because her strength was not tried , was quite impatient for the concert evening .

text: She had once partly promised Mrs Smith to spend the evening with her ; but in a short hurried call she excused herself and put it off , with the more decided promise of a longer visit on the morrow .

text: Mrs Smith gave a most good - humoured acquiescence .

text: " By all means , " said she ; " only tell me all about it , when you do come .

text: Who is your party ?

text: Anne named them all . Mrs Smith made no reply ; but when she was leaving her said , and with an expression half serious , half arch , " Well , I heartily wish your concert may answer ; and do not fail me to - morrow if you can come ; for I begin to have a foreboding that I may not have many more visits from you . " Anne was startled and confused ; but after standing in a moment 's suspense , was obliged , and not sorry to be obliged , to hurry away .

" Anne was startled and confused ; but after standing in a moment 's suspense , was obliged , and not sorry to be obliged , to hurry away .
